notes:
1. Concept

The Pressure-Volume (P-v) diagram is a graph that plots Pressure ($P$) on the vertical axis versus Specific Volume ($v$) on the horizontal axis. It is one of the most common diagrams used to visualize thermodynamic processes, especially for piston-cylinder systems.

2. Key Feature: Work Done

The most important property of a P-v diagram is that for a quasi-equilibrium process, the area under the process curve represents the boundary work ($W_b$) done by or on the system.

$$ W_b = \int_{1}^{2} P dv $$
  • Expansion ($dv > 0$): The area is positive, meaning work is done by the system (e.g., power stroke in an engine).
  • Compression ($dv < 0$): The area is negative (conceptually), meaning work is done on the system.
  • Cycle: The net work done during a cycle is equal to the area enclosed by the cycle path. A clockwise cycle produces net work output (heat engine).

3. Common Processes on P-v Diagram

  • Isobaric ($P=C$): A horizontal line. Work is simply $P(v_2 - v_1)$.
  • Isochoric ($v=C$): A vertical line. The area under the curve is zero, so no boundary work is done.
  • Isothermal/Adiabatic: Both are curves sloping downwards ($P$ decreases as $v$ increases). An adiabatic curve is steeper than an isothermal curve for the same gas.

solvedExamples.question: On a P-v diagram, the area under the process curve represents:
solvedExamples.explanation: Boundary work for a quasi-equilibrium process is defined as $W = \int P dv$. This integral corresponds geometrically to the area under the curve plotted on a Pressure-Volume diagram.

solvedExamples.question: An isochoric (constant volume) process appears on a P-v diagram as:
solvedExamples.explanation: Since the specific volume $v$ is constant, the process moves vertically up or down at a fixed x-coordinate value. Since there is no change in volume ($dv=0$), the area under this vertical line is zero, confirming that no boundary work is done.
